meta.title: Coronavirus & Illness Updates - Franklin Public Schools

meta.name: description
meta.content: Coronavirus & Illness Updates - Franklin Public Schools

Coronavirus & Illness Updates - Franklin Public Schools

li.a: Gifted Learner Parent and/or Teacher Referral Form
Onsite Counseling Clinics at Franklin Public Schools
STOPit Bullying and Threats of Violence Reporting
STOPit Bullying and Threats of Violence Reporting
Saber Center for the Performing Arts

div.div: Our MissionFranklin Public Schools inspires personal success through learning experiences that focus on student needs and active partnerships with family and community.

Our SchoolsFranklin Public Schools has 7 buildings in our district: 5 elementary schools, one middle school and one high school. Our staff is dedicated to providing excellent educational opportunities from Kindergarten through 12th grade.

Student-Focused At the Franklin Public School District, students are the center of everything we do! With the support of our school community, the dedication of our school staff and the assistance of many volunteers, we continue to demonstrate excellence in student learning and achievement at all levels.

li.a: STOPit Bullying and Threats of Violence Reporting

div.div: Welcome to FPS!Thank you for your interest in joining our District- we are honored you chose Franklin Public Schools for your children. We look forward to meeting you!

Connecting You to FPS Franklin Public Schools values the involvement of the entire Franklin community in our District. To find out more about us, we encourage you to explore our website, attend our student performances, events and competitions, or visit one of our schools.

li.a: STOPit Bullying and Threats of Violence Reporting
Saber Center for the Performing Arts

div.div: Contact FPSOur staff is here to assist you with any needs you may have. Please reach out to us today!

img.alt: Student and Teacher Work at Desk

p.em: This page serves as the Franklin Public Schools resource for any news and updates related to Coronavirus (COVID-19) or other spreading illnesses.

li.em: Please find the most recent updates about Franklin on the Franklin Health Department Facebook page here.
Currently, all Franklin Public Schools are closed as of Monday, March 16. This includes all Franklin Community Education & Recreation Department activities and events, including Kids Club.

p.em: The following is a list of communications about COVID-19 and our Franklin Public Schools response:

ul.li: Wed, April 1, 2020 @ 2:45pm - 5K-4 Virtual Learning Plan Information for Families
Fri, March 27, 2020 @ 2pm - Family Newsletter & Updates from Dr. Mueller (includes food plan)
Wed, March 18, 2020 @ 4:30pm - Message From Our FPS Nurses
Tues, March 17, 2020 @ 12:45pm - FPS Offering Lunches to Any Child Ages 2-18
Mon, March 16, 2020 @ 3pm - FPS Virtual Learning Days Information for families
Sun, March 15, 2020 @ 12:15pm - To all families regarding Free & Reduced Lunch students, Health Dept Updates
Sat, March 14, 2020 @ 12pm - FPS Virtual Learning Information Coming Monday
Fri, March 13, 2020 @ 4pm - Gov Evers Mandates All Wisconsin Schools Close
Fri, March 13, 2020 @ 2:15pm - FPS Closing Letter for Mon, March 16 through Spring Break
Thurs, March 12, 2020 - Update From Franklin Public Schools
Fri, March 6, 2020 - All Buildings Newsletter Article for Families

p.strong: This Page Last Updated: Thurs, March 19, 2020

li.a: Are Franklin Community Ed & Rec Programs occuring?
What if I have to get a hold of someone at FPS?

h2.a: When will FPS re-open?

div.p: Per the mandate from Governor Evers to close all Wisconsin K-12 public and private schools, we are currently closed through Sunday, April 5th. The state has said that date might change as more information becomes available. That is currently the timeframe we are operating under.

h2.a: Are Franklin Community Ed & Rec Programs occuring?

div.p: No. All Franklin Public Schools events and activities are canceled. This includes all Franklin Community Education & Recreation programming and activities, as well as Kids Club.

h2.a: How will "virtual learning days" work?

div.p: More detailed communication will be coming to families on Monday, March 16 regarding how virtual learning days will be conducted. Our staff is still finalizing the details. We plan to start virtual learning days for students on Wednesday, March 18. Thank you for your patience as our teaching staff uses the time on Monday and Tuesday to prepare content and materials for our virtual learning days.

h2.a: What if I have to get a hold of someone at FPS?

div.p: Please use the Staff Directory page to search for the person you need to contact. Email is a better option for contacting staff at this time. Staff should be periodically checking voicemail as well.
As we move into virtual learning days beginning Wednesday, March 18, parents will receive more email communication from principals and/or teachers in regards to how learning will continue.

li.a: Even with schools closed, should we still complete the District Travel form?
Do we have to self-quarantine if we return from a trip?
What if we have travel or spring break plans?

h2.a: Even with schools closed, should we still complete the District Travel form?

div.p: As shared in the March 12, 2020 update from Dr. Mueller, we are asking District families and staff that are planning travel before April 12, 2020 to please make us aware of these plans by filling out this form. Even though schools have been closed, it is still helpful for our District Nurses to have this information as we work on returning all students to school.

h2.a: Do we have to self-quarantine if we return from a trip?

li.p: The U.S. State Department has warned that travelers should prepare for restrictions with little or no notice.

Individuals returning from Europe, China, Iran, South Korea, and Italy locations will be asked to stay home for a period of 14 days upon their return under the direction of their local health department and the CDC.

h2.a: What if we have travel or spring break plans?

li.p: The CDC recommends avoiding nonessential travel. If you are planning to travel within the United States, the CDC offers guidance for you to consider regarding your plans.

There are also specified travel destinations with continuously evolving guidelines, which currently include Europe, China, Iran, South Korea, and Italy. Individuals returning from these locations will be asked to stay home for a period of 14 days upon their return under the direction of their local health department and the CDC.
A list of countries where community spread of COVID-19 is occurring can be found on the CDC webpage.
Please share any travel that is occurring before April 12, 2020 with us by filling out this form.

li.a: What are other resources I can explore?
How can I talk to my child about COVID-19?

h2.a: What actions is FPS taking?

ol.li: District Nurses review illness logs and symptom trends from the school health rooms and evaluate attendance reports daily.
District Nurses consult with health room staff around when to send home students with a potentially contagious illness.
District Buildings and Grounds staff and custodial teams work daily to maintain our schools to their highest standard. They are stocked and prepared for an increase in illnesses.
FPS maintains an ongoing partnership with the Franklin Health Department for coordination of preparedness plans so the District response is aligned with local and state recommendations.
All District staff play a role in communicating about daily observations made in school buildings related to signs of illness and prevention efforts.

h2.a: What are other resources I can explore?

ol.li: At this time, influenza is still having a much bigger impact on the health of Americans than COVID-19. Learn more from the CDC about what you can do to keep yourselves and your family healthy!

h2.a: How can I talk to my child about COVID-19?

ul.li: The needs of every child are different in terms of the support that they require during times that may cause stress. The World Health Organization (WHO) and the National Association of School Psychologists (NASP) released a few beneficial parent resources for talking to children about COVID-19.

li.a: What are some good prevention strategies?
What should I do if I have symptoms (fever, cough, fatigue, shortness of breath)?
Should my child or I be wearing a face mask to decrease our chances of being exposed?

h2.a: What are some good prevention strategies?

p.em: The following are suggested strategies for preventing illnesses, including Coronavirus.

ul.li: Stay home when you are sick
Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth with unwashed hands
Cover your cough and sneeze with a tissue and wash your hands
Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains 60% alcohol
Avoid close contact with people who are sick
Currently, it is not a recommendation from the CDC or Department of Health to wear a mask

h2.a: What should I do if I have symptoms (fever, cough, fatigue, shortness of breath)?

ol.li: Contact your doctor’s office or healthcare provider immediately
Avoid contact with others as much as possible
Do not go to work or school

p.em: The CDC offers additional guidance here related to prevention of spread of the virus and actions to take if you think you or a family member may have COVID-19.

h2.a: Should my child or I be wearing a face mask to decrease our chances of being exposed?

div.p: CDC does not recommend that people who are well wear a face mask to protect themselves from respiratory diseases, including COVID-19.

li.p: Face masks should be used by people who are ill to help prevent the spread of the disease to others. Face masks may also be worn by individuals with certain chronic health conditions whose providers may recommend that they do so.
The use of face masks is also crucial for health care workers and people who are taking care of someone in close settings (at home or in a health care facility).

h2.a: What is Coronavirus (COVID-19)?

div.p: COVID-19, the 2019 novel coronavirus, a strain of coronavirus, was first reported in Wuhan, China in late 2019. The virus, also referred to as SARS-CoV-2 (severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2), has since spread globally. Much is still being learned about the disease, including:

ol.li: How long it takes to begin to show symptoms after being exposed to the virus
How severe the symptoms of illness will be in an individual with coronavirus
Exactly how the disease can be spread

em.a: Learn more about COVID-19 from the CDC by clicking here

h2.a: How is Coronavirus (COVID-19) spread?

div.p: COVID-19 appears to be spread primarily through droplets from the throat and nose. This means that people with COVID-19 can spread it to others when they cough, sneeze, or even talk if someone else near them breathes in those droplets. The droplets may also be on objects or surfaces, so if an individual comes into contact with those objects and touches their mouth or eyes, the virus can spread.

h2.a: What are the signs & symptoms?

p.em: (Remember, COVID-19 symptoms are similar to many other respiratory illnesses)

ol.li: Fever
Coughing
Fatigue and/or body aches
Shortness of breath
Headache
Sore throat
Abdominal pain
Diarrhea

h2.a: Who is at risk?

div.p: While there have been confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the US, in general, the immediate risk to the public is low. Unless your family or child has recently traveled to China, Japan, South Korea, Italy or Iran, or you have been exposed to someone currently being treated for COVID-19, your risk is very low. Current studies have shown that older adults and individuals with chronic health conditions are at higher risk of being impacted by the illness.
The majority of patients with COVID-19 outside of Wuhan, China currently appear to have a mild illness.

li.a: Can my doctor’s office or medical provider test me or my family member for COVID-19?
Is there a vaccine for COVID-19?
What treatment is offered for someone with confirmed COVID-19?

h2.a: Can my doctor’s office or medical provider test me or my family member for COVID-19?

div.p: Your doctors or health care providers will work with our local and state health departments and the CDC to determine if testing is required based on symptoms and potential exposures.

h2.a: Is there a vaccine for COVID-19?

div.p: No vaccine against COVID-19 is currently available, but work to develop vaccines is ongoing.

h2.a: What treatment is offered for someone with confirmed COVID-19?

div.p: Currently, there are no specific treatments for COVID-19. Supportive therapies (including fluids and rest) may help relieve symptoms.

p.span: 8255 West Forest Hill Avenue, Franklin, Wisconsin 53132
